conclusion: Consider forces acting on each block and relationship between applied force F, acceleration, and static friction force.
Block A, B, C, and D are placed on a smooth horizontal surface with blocks B and C connected by a light spring.
A horizontal pulling force F is applied to block B.
Identify the forces acting on each block: Block A, B, C, and D have force F applied by the spring.
Apply Newton's second law: For each block, F = ma.
Total force F is the same for all blocks since they are identical and force F is applied to all.
Blocks are accelerating together with the same acceleration, so net force acting on each block must be zero.
Net force acting on each block is the sum of forces exerted by the spring and applied force F.
Force exerted by the spring on each block is F.
Force exerted by the applied force F on each block is F.
Since blocks are accelerating together with the same acceleration, net force acting on each block is zero.
Force exerted by the applied force F on each block must be equal to the force exerted by the spring on each block.
Force exerted by the spring on each block is F.
Since blocks are identical and force F is applied to all, force exerted by the spring on each block must be the same.
Force exerted by the spring on each block is F.
Force exerted by the applied force F on each block is F.
Since blocks are accelerating together with the same acceleration, net force acting on each block must be zero.
Force exerted by the applied force F on each block must be equal to the force exerted by the spring on each block.
Force exerted by the spring on each block is F.
Since blocks are identical and force F is applied to all, force exerted by the spring on each block must be the same.
Force exerted by the spring on each block is F.
Force exerted by the applied force F on each block is F.
